conclusion: For an ideal gas, the specific internal energy depends only on temperature: U = U(T).
In the p-V diagram, every point (p, V) on a given adiabat satisfies p V^Î³ = constant (Î³ = C_p/C_v > 1).
Points c and a lie on two different adiabats. Their volumes and pressures are such that V_c = V_b and V_a = V_d.
p_c > p_a as the curve through c is everywhere above the curve through a.
Because p_c > p_a at the same volume, it would also mean T_c > T_a using the ideal-gas relation pV = nRT.
Since U depends only on T, the larger temperature implies the larger internal energy.
U_c > U_a (the internal energy at state c is greater than at state a).
